text: {{Infobox chef | name = Leah Chase | image = LeahChaseAp08Crop.jpg | caption = Leah Chase in April 2008 | birth_date = | birth_place = New Orleans, Louisiana, U.S. | death_date = | death_place = New Orleans, Louisiana, U.S. | spouse = Edgar "Dooky" Chase II (m. 1946; died 2016) | children = 4 | style = Creole | education = Colonial Restaurant, French Quarter, New Orleans, United States | ratings = | restaurants = Dooky Chase | awards = }} Leah Chase (January 6, 1923 - June 1, 2019) was an American chef, author and television personality. She was born in New Orleans but was raised in Madisonville, Louisiana, before moving back to New Orleans to attend catholic school. Chase was known as the Queen of Creole Cuisine. She supported African-American art and Creole cooking. Her restaurant, Dooky Chase, was known as a gathering place during the 1960s among many who participated in the Civil Rights Movement. Chase died on June 1, 2019 in New Orleans, Louisiana at the age of 96.Leah Chase, New Orleans’ matriarch of Creole cuisine, dead at 96 ==References== ==Other websites== *Leah Chase New Orleans Online *Lifetime Achievement Award – Leah Chase Southern Foodways Alliance (2000) *Allen, Carol Listen, I Say Like This (biography of Leah Chase) (2002) *Leah Chase of Dooky Chase Restaurant St. Mary's Academy Newsletter Category:1923 births Category:2019 deaths Category:American television personalities Category:American civil rights activists Category:American chefs Category:Writers from New Orleans
